Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Sammanfattande bakgrund till stödet ILO är FN:s fackliga organ för frågor med koppling till produktiv sysselsättning med anständiga arbetsvillkor, och en ledande normativ och standardsättande aktör. ILO:s "Decent work"-agenda - med inriktning på arbetsrätt, social dialog, sysselsättning och sociala skyddsnät - utgör ett ramverk för att bidra till fattigdomsminskning och mänskliga rättigheter på global, regional och nationell nivå. Samarbete mellan regeringar, arbetsgivar- och arbetstagarorganisationer - den s.k. "trepartsstrukturen" - är en central del av ILO:s uppbyggnad och sätt att arbeta. ILO:s verksamhet är relevant inom de flesta områden som rör utveckling och fattigdomsbekämpning, såsom; mänskliga rättigheter (inklusive barns rättigheter), konfliktförebyggande, ekonomisk hållbar utveckling, migration etc. Detta är kopplat till det faktum att sysselsättning är en multisektoriell, övergripande ämnesfråga som relaterar till alla delar av samhället och människors liv.
Sida har arbetat med ILO som partner sedan 70-talet, och på global nivå sedan ett tiotal år tillbaka. Erfarenheterna från tidigare samarbete är generellt goda. Förutom att arbeta genom sina konventioner och rekommendationer, med tillhörande standarder, är ILO ledande inom policy- och metodutveckling, datainsamling/analys samt kapacitetsbyggande inom sysselsättningsområdet. ILO är även en operativ organisation med kontor i 42 länder runtom i världen. ILO:s kapacitet på landnivå är skiftande, mycket på grund av att en stor andel av personalen i fält finansieras genom projekt. Kapaciteten och kunskapen hos personalen på de fast bemannade kontoren bedöms dock vara hög, och ILO har ofta ett starkt mandat på landnivå genom sin trepartsstruktur. Det trepartiska arbetssättet gör att ILO å ena sidan kan uppfattas som tungrott, å andra sidan som en organisation som arbetar långsiktigt mot hållbar utveckling.
Sverige, genom Sida, är den sjunde största bilaterala givaren till ILO. Sida stödjer ILO:s utvecklingssamarbete på bilateral, regional och global nivå. Utöver detta ansvarar Arbetsmarknadsdepartementet för Sveriges medlemsavgift till ILO, vilken uppgår till ca 31,5 MSEK per år. Utrikesdepartementet (UD) har kanaliserat ett mindre stöd till ILO under 2017, genom dess Global Deal-sekretariat.
Trots att Sverige och Sida inte är en av ILO:s största givare finns relativt goda möjligheter till påverkan. Dels kan Sida påverka genom givargruppen. Dels kan Arbetsmarknadsdepartementet och UD påverka genom ILO:s styrande organ Governing Body (GB) och International Labour Conference (ILC). De svenska parterna - arbetsgivar- och arbetstagarorganisationerna - kan också driva svenska prioriterade frågor genom sina kanaler.
Stödets inriktning Föreslaget stöd gäller globalt programstöd till ILO för åren 2018-2020 i form av lätt öronmärkt, tematiskt stöd (s.k. "Outcome"-stöd, i enlighet med ILO:s tvååriga planering ) samt oöronmärkt stöd till ILO:s DAC-fäiga arbete till "Regular Budget Supplementary Account" (RBSA) fördelat enligt följande:
- Tematiskt stöd/Outcome-stöd, totalt: 83 MSEK Outcome 1 (Fler och bättre jobb för människor i fattigdom, inklusive för ungdomar): 30 MSEK Outcome 8 (Oacceptabla arbetsförhållanden): 21 MSEK Genderintegrering: 10,5 MSEK Miljö- och klimatintegrering: 10,5 MSEK Integrering av social dialog och "Global Deal": 11 MSEK
- Oöronmärkt stöd till RBSA: 55 MSEK
Storleken på stödet är i linje med tidigare avtalsperiod (2014-2017) och inriktningen i stort densamma. De huvudsakliga skillnaderna utgörs av: - större andel oöronmärkt stöd - nytt stöd till social dialog som tvärfråga - inget projektstöd.
Stödet till ILO:s integrerings/tvärfrågor bygger på organisationens egna markörer för tvärfrågor.
Inriktningen på stödet ligger väl i linje med ILO:s egna prioriteringar samt svenska prioriterade frågor inom utvecklingssamarbetet i allmänhet, och inom området hållbar ekonomisk utveckling i synnerhet.
Sida bedömer att nivån på stödet är i linje med ILO:s absorptionskapacitet. Möjlighet finns dock att öka stödet till vissa delar, såsom den flexibla RBSA-mekanismen.

ILO's programme and budget for the biennium 2018 - 2019 includes ten policy outcomes that reflect the priorities of the organisation, aimed at the promotion of social justice through the Decent Work Agenda and its strategic objectives of employment, social protection, social dialogue and tripartism, and fundamental principles and rights at work. Sida's support will focus on the two following policy outcomes: Policy Outcome 1 - More and better jobs for inclusive growth and improved youth employment prospects: Member states implement policies and programmes that promote more and better jobs and enhance youth employment prospects with a view to inclusive growth and development. Policy Outcome 8 - Protecting workers from unacceptable forms of work: Member states develop or enhance laws and policies, strenghten institutions, and foster partnerships to protect women and men from unacceptable forms of work.

tag.narrative: 8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.

8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.5 - Senast 2030 uppnå full och produktiv sysselsättning med anständiga arbetsvillkor för alla kvinnor och män, inklusive ungdomar och personer med funktionsnedsättning, samt lika lön för likvärdigt arbete.
8.5 - By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.
8.6 - Till 2020 väsentligt minska den andel ungdomar som varken arbetar eller studerar.
8.6 - By 2020, substantially reduce the proportion of youth not in employment, education or training.
8.8 - Protect labour rights and promote safe and secure working environments for all workers, including migrant workers, in particular women migrants, and those in precarious employment.

8.8 - Skydda arbetstagarnas rättigheter och främja en trygg och säker arbetsmiljö för alla arbetstagare, inklusive arbetskraftsinvandrare, i synnerhet kvinnliga migranter, och människor i otrygga anställningar.
8.b - By 2020, develop and operationalize a global strategy for youth employment and implement the Global Jobs Pact of the International Labour Organization.
8.b - Senast 2020 utarbeta och börja tillämpa en global strategi för ungdomssysselsättning samt genomföra Internationella arbetsorganisationens globala sysselsättningspakt.

description.narrative: Each outcome has indicators, ways of measurement, baselines and targets linked to it in the Programme and Budget. Progress and achievements related to these indicators are reviewed and reported through the ILO “Programme Implementation Report” (PIR) at the end of each biennium. The next PIR covering the biennium 2018-19 will be published in 2020. The below summary of results is based mainly on the 2018 Progress Report for the Sida-ILO Partnership Programme. Outcome 1: More and better jobs for inclusive growth and improved youth employment prospects Under this outcome, the focus of interventions for Sida’s support is 1) strengthening employment policy diagnostics and implementation, 2) targeted policies and programmes on youth employment, with focus on vulnerable youth, and 3) sectoral focus for skills anticipation through the strengthening of the “Skills for Trade and Economic Diversification” (STED) programme. At the global level, the support has contributed to sharpen diagnostics, analysis and tool to support advocacy and make the ILO more influential in the global policy debates on employment. The current partnership supports the design of high-profile reports and studies which will enable renewed policy analysis and advise for action to decision-makers. Examples of this is: the start of a global research on “SDG and employment policies: Macroeconomic and sectoral policies for structural transformation and full and productive employment” covering ten countries; the outlines of a Youth Employment Toolbox to be developed and operational in 2019; and technical guidance and backstopping to five on-going STED-based projects. At country level, Sida support is responding to specific needs in various steps of the policy cycle in different countries, such as; targeting the most vulnerable groups such as NEETS (neither in employment nor in education or training), rural workers, women, youth, people working in the informal sector, etc., building capacity and supporting implementation to enable sustainability, support pilots or innovations, and to have a leveraging or catalytic effect. For example, the regional employment programmes in Morrocco supported through the global Sida-ILO Partnership Programme was the first of its kind, following the national employment action plan of the country, and is carried out in three pilot regions focusing on vulnerable groups such as rural population, women and NEETs. From this initiative, the ILO is able to draw lessons and capitalise to serve other countries and similar strategies, which is also an important aspect related to country level support through the global Sida-ILO Partnership Prgoramme – namely that it should have global added value and create linkages between the Decent Work Country Programmes and Country Programme Outcomes, and ILO’s global products and normative work, and together contribute to the overall ILO Programme and Budget (P&B). The initiative will also coordinate with the Sida funded regional programme “Advancing the Decent Work Agenda in North Africa", and will look towards complementarity of funds and joint activities to be defined. Outcome 7: Promoting safe work and workplace compliance including in global supply chains Under this outcome, Sida’s support is focused under indicator 7.3 “Number of member states that have developed or strengthened institutions for tripartite social dialogue collective bargaining and industrial relations with a view to addressing inequality and enhancing workplace compliance, including in global chains” and has contributed to the development of selected global outputs for the promotion of social dialogue, industrial relations and collective bargaining. At global level, main activities under this outcome has been updates and strengthening of key ILO knowledge generation and management toolbox, in terms of development of for example databases such as the Legal Database on Industrial Relations, and the Industrial Relations Database. In addition, progress have been made to finalise the development of Industrial Relations Toolkits which is a policy and capacity building resources package covering key industrial relations subjects such as collective bargaining, workplace cooperation and grievance handling. Work is also underway to develop a new tool for constituents to conduct comprehensive participatory assessments of their national social dialogue institutions in line with relevant international labour standards. These global products provide support to the ILO’s operations at the field level in line with selected Country Programme Outcomes aiming to achieve ILO’s strategy for Outcome 7, with specific focus on ODA-eligible countries. For example, these tools have been tested at country level in collaboration with ILO field offices and in complementarity with relevant ILO projects, for example Public-Private Partnerships (PPDPs) on national and regional level between Sida, ILO and H&M in Bangladesh, Cambodia, Myanmar, Ethiopia and at regional level in Asia. Outcome 8: Protecting workers from unacceptable forms of work Under this Outcome, focus continues to be on sectors and occupations in which women and men workers from disadvantaged communities are predominately employed, with specific attention to indigenous workers and migrant workers who are particularly vulnerable to discriminatory employment practices and exploitive working conditions. At global level, Sida’s contribution is supporting the operationalisation of the Equal Pay International Coalition (EPIC), which is a multi-stakeholder coalition led by the ILO, UN Women and OECD, and the preparatory work and follow-up to the standard-setting on ending violence and harassment in the world of work. At country level, the support has contributed to interventions which aims at strengthening the protection of workers from indigenous communities with a focus on indigenous women in female-dominated sectors and occupations, and in urban informal economy and traditionally male-dominated sectors. For example, in Bangladesh a project has supported the Bangladesh Tea Workers Union in concluding the collective bargaining negotiations. A collective agreement between Bangladesh Cha Shramik Union and Bangladesh Tea Association was signed in August 2018 for the period of 2017-2018. The Ministry of Labour and Employment and the Bangladesh Tea Association agreed in a tripartite consultation workshop to monitor the full implementation of the agreement. Cross-Cutting Policy Driver: Just Transition to Environmental Sustainability Sida’s contribution has been used towards developing a consolidated ILO approach for environmental sustainability through the establishments of practical tools and guidance, expanding policy advice on just transition, and enhancing capacity in the Africa region to integrate environmental sustainability in the decent work agenda and promote green jobs with a focus on women and youth. At the global level, a framework and set of tools for a Rapid Situational Analysis for a Just Transition (RSA-JT) have been developed. The RSA-JT framework and tools allow a quick and systematic analysis of the country context in order to identify high-potential entry points on assistance to Just Transition, also taking into consideration specific target groups such as women and youth. It also facilitates mainstreaming of environmental sustainability in the ILO programming as well as inform the focus of research and policy advice. Sida’s support has also contributed to consolidating the Green Jobs Assessment Institutions Network (GAIN), through which three webinars have been have been developed and delivered on employment-environmental linkages and relevant methods for assessment. At country level, the above-mentioned RSA-JT has been applied in two countries (Tanzania and Ghana). In Tanzania the analysis and consultations with constituents led to the identification of the horticulture sector as focus for further intervention, also due to its potential for job creation for women and youth. An environmentally sensitive market system analysis, the fist of its kind, has been conducted and will contribute to design of a pilot application as well as policy and programme recommendations. The Swedish senior secondment to ILOs regional office in Dar es Salaam (Gun Eriksson Skoog), with specific expertise in the markets system development approach has been involved in this work. Cross-Cutting Policy Driver: Gender Equality and Non-discrimination Sida’s support builds on previous support contributing to the gender mainstreaming policy driver, as well as the Women@Work centenary initiative. It is focused on the thematic priorities of the Women at Work Initiative: inceasing women’s access to quality work; promoting equal pay; the care economy and will reinforce data and knowledge base for policy action, and operationalisation of the CCPD at country level. At global level, Sida’s support has contributed to increased visibility of the EPIC (mentioned above) on international level, for example at the High Level Event “Demonstrating commitment and leadership on equal pay – an EPIC Pledgin event” at UNGA in 2018, the ILO “Care work and care jobs for the future of decent work”-report, as well as tools and care policies extended to the informal economy conceptualized in collaboration with WIEGO. At regional level, the support to a project working to strengthen the capacity of the West African Economic and Monetary Union (WAEMU) to take appropriate measures to promote gender quality, led to the Labour and Social Dialogue Council of WAEMU adopting a decision on equal opportunities and equal treatment of women in the world of work.
